REPUBLIC OF SOUTH AFRICA
Case NO. 450/96
THE SUPREME COURT OF APPEAL
OF SOUTH AFRICA
In the matter between:
IVOR NISELOW
APPELLANT
and
LIBERTY LIFE ASSOCIATION
OF AFRICA LIMITED
RESPONDENT
BEFORE: MAHOMED CJ, VAN HEERDEN DCJ, HARMS, ZULMAN and STREICHER JJA
DATE HEARD:
19 MAY 1998
DATE DELIVERED: 27 MAY 1998
JUDGMENT STREICHER,JA:
In terms of a written agreement respondent, an insurance
2 company, appointed appellant as its "agent". Pursuant to disciplinary inquiries
respondent terminated the agreement. Appellant thereupon instituted
proceedings in the Industrial Court in terms of which he claimed payment of
certain losses allegedly suffered by him as a result of the termination of the
agreement. He alleged that he was entitled to payment of these losses in that
his "dismissal" constituted an unfair labour practice in terms of the since
repealed Labour Relations Act, 1956 ("the Act").
Respondent in limine raised the defence that the Industrial Court
had no jurisdiction in respect of appellant's claim in that appellant had not
been an "employee" as defined in the Act. By agreement between the parties
the Industrial Court first tried the point in limine. It found that appellant was
an employee as envisaged by the Act and dismissed that point. An appeal to
the Labour Appeal Court was, however, successful. The point was upheld,
resulting in the dismissal of appellant's application with costs. With the leave
3
of the Labour Appeal Court appellant now appeals to this court.
The only issue raised by the appeal is whether appellant was an "employee" of respondent as defined in s 1(1) of the Act.
If not, the Industrial Court had no jurisdiction in respect of the dispute between the parties.

respondents: LIBERTY LIFE ASSOCIATION OF AFRICA LIMITED

sections.facts: The appellant, Ivor Niselow, was appointed by the respondent, Liberty Life Association of Africa Ltd, as its "agent" under a written agreement. The respondent subsequently terminated the agreement following disciplinary inquiries. Niselow instituted proceedings in the Industrial Court, claiming damages for losses he alleged resulted from an unfair labour practice – specifically his dismissal – under the Labour Relations Act, 1956. The Industrial Court first addressed a preliminary jurisdictional issue, finding that Niselow qualified as an "employee" within the meaning of the Act and therefore proceeded with the case. The Labour Appeal Court later reversed that finding, holding that he was not an employee, dismissing his claim with costs. The present appeal challenges that decision.
sections.issues: The sole issue on appeal is whether the appellant was an "employee" of the respondent as defined in section 1(1) of the Labour Relations Act, 1956. This determination is pivotal because it governs the Industrial Court's jurisdiction over the dispute.
sections.principles: The court must apply the statutory definition of "employee" in the Labour Relations Act, which requires a contract of service characterized by the employer's right to control the manner in which work is performed. Jurisdiction of the Industrial Court is dependent upon the existence of an employment relationship as defined by the Act. Precedent establishes that an agency relationship, absent the essential elements of a contract of service, does not create employee status.
sections.application: The court examined the nature of the agreement between Niselow and Liberty Life, focusing on whether the terms created a contract of service or merely an agency relationship. It considered the degree of control exercised by the respondent over Niselow's work, the remuneration structure, and the obligations imposed on each party. Finding that the relationship lacked the requisite control and mutual obligations typical of employment, the court concluded that Niselow was not an employee within the meaning of the Act.
sections.conclusion: The appeal is allowed. The appellant is held not to be an employee under the Labour Relations Act, and consequently the Industrial Court lacked jurisdiction to hear his unfair labour practice claim. The appellant's application is dismissed with costs.
